awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Triassic-Jurassic Fossils and the Origin of the Crocodilian Skull
awd_abstract_narration:
Crocodilians and their closest relatives have an exceptional fossil record from the last 250 million years, documenting the origins of their many specializations. Here the PIs investigate for the first time the origins of the unique jaw-closing system that allows crocodilians to have the strongest bite force of any vertebrate, using biomechanical analyses integrated with a study of their evolutionary relationships. The PIs will also study how the size of air spaces in the skull relates to a dramatic increase in global temperatures and decrease in atmospheric oxygen at the end of the Triassic Period. The study seeks to determine whether the origin of features increasing bite force were related to the increase in air spaces in the skull, or whether these two signature adaptations of modern crocodilians evolved independently.
 
Crocodilians are charismatic animals that lend themselves well to educational outreach, and this project will utilize the Smithsonian?s National Museum of Natural History's Q'rius learning center and University of Missouri's Inside Dinosaurs program as platforms to contribute to public scientific literacy and public engagement with science. The PIs and their students will engage in public presentations and develop interactive experiences based on 3D skulls printed from project CT scans. Collaboration with researchers in China will strengthen international collaboration.

por.por_cntn:
Living crocodilians are highly specialized semi-aquatic carnivores, with a skull specialized to withstand the forces from muscles producing the strongest bite of any living animal, and this project examined the transition from the ancestral skull condition to the evolutionary appearances of many of these cranial specializations.  This was done in collaboration with a project examining the changes in musculature during this transition and its effects on bite forces.  CT scans of the cranial anatomy of extinct species of Late Triassic and Jurassic crocodylomorphs ("sphenosuchians" and "protosuchians") were processed to isolate 3D images of the individual bones, describe them, and extract characters for phylogenetic analysis.  The primary publication of this project was a detailed description of the skulls of two "sphenosuchians", Dibothrosuchus and Junggarsuchus, documenting the solidification of the skull in species close to the origin of Crocodyliformes and presenting a new evolutionary tree (phylogeny) of early crocodylian relatives (https://doi.org/10.1002/ar.24949).  This phylogeny was used in a study by our collaborators of the changes in bite force in the evolution of early crocodylomorphs (https://anatomypubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ar.24912).  Images from the processed CT scans of these two species and the phylogeny are provided with this report.

This project involved collaborations with institutions and scientists in China and South Africa, the source area for the most relevant fossils outside of North America, including fossils Clark collected in collaborative field projects in both countries.  Clark mentored a PhD student at the University of the Witwatersrand in South Africa, Kathleen Dollman, who studied the cranial anatomy of South African "protosuchians".  The project's primary publication was the result of 4 years of work by GWU BS/MS student Alex Ruebenstahl, working with Clark, and Ruebenstahl is continuing his studies on fossil crocodylomorphs in the Yale PhD program.  During the course of this project Clark advised a PBS documentary that included a segment on the evolution of crocodilians ("When Whales Walked: Journeys in Deep Time").  CT scans of the skulls of three species representing stages in the evolution of the crocodylian skull were processed and printed in resin and form a learning module in the education section (Q?rius) of the National Museum of Natural History.  This project yielded 10 peer-reviewed publications, and data and processed scans used in the primary publication are available to the public on the Dryad website (https://datadryad.org/stash/dataset/doi:10.5061/dryad.5hqbzkh5k).  


Last Modified: 12/01/2022
Modified by: James M Clark

por.por_txt_cntn:
Living crocodilians are highly specialized semi-aquatic carnivores, with a skull specialized to withstand the forces from muscles producing the strongest bite of any living animal, and this project examined the transition from the ancestral skull condition to the evolutionary appearances of many of these cranial specializations.  This was done in collaboration with a project examining the changes in musculature during this transition and its effects on bite forces.  CT scans of the cranial anatomy of extinct species of Late Triassic and Jurassic crocodylomorphs ("sphenosuchians" and "protosuchians") were processed to isolate 3D images of the individual bones, describe them, and extract characters for phylogenetic analysis.  The primary publication of this project was a detailed description of the skulls of two "sphenosuchians", Dibothrosuchus and Junggarsuchus, documenting the solidification of the skull in species close to the origin of Crocodyliformes and presenting a new evolutionary tree (phylogeny) of early crocodylian relatives (https://doi.org/10.1002/ar.24949).  This phylogeny was used in a study by our collaborators of the changes in bite force in the evolution of early crocodylomorphs (https://anatomypubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ar.24912).  Images from the processed CT scans of these two species and the phylogeny are provided with this report.

This project involved collaborations with institutions and scientists in China and South Africa, the source area for the most relevant fossils outside of North America, including fossils Clark collected in collaborative field projects in both countries.  Clark mentored a PhD student at the University of the Witwatersrand in South Africa, Kathleen Dollman, who studied the cranial anatomy of South African "protosuchians".  The project's primary publication was the result of 4 years of work by GWU BS/MS student Alex Ruebenstahl, working with Clark, and Ruebenstahl is continuing his studies on fossil crocodylomorphs in the Yale PhD program.  During the course of this project Clark advised a PBS documentary that included a segment on the evolution of crocodilians ("When Whales Walked: Journeys in Deep Time").  CT scans of the skulls of three species representing stages in the evolution of the crocodylian skull were processed and printed in resin and form a learning module in the education section (Q?rius) of the National Museum of Natural History.  This project yielded 10 peer-reviewed publications, and data and processed scans used in the primary publication are available to the public on the Dryad website (https://datadryad.org/stash/dataset/doi:10.5061/dryad.5hqbzkh5k).
